captions.text:
00:05
COMM: These carnivorous plants make light

work of any insects that stray into their
deadly clutches.

00:14
COMM: The Cape sundew, native to South Africa,

lures ants and flies in with drops of sweet
smelling fluid on the highly adhesive tentacles

00:29
COMM: Surrounding tentacles then move further

to ensnare the insect, before glands on the
leaf start to release digestive enzymes.

00:43
COMM: A Venus flytrap leaf is divided into

to halfs, fringed with stiff spikes. Each
plant carries three touch sensitive hairs,

and when two are touched in quick succession,
the trap is triggered, imprisoning the fly.

01:10
COMM: And while these carnivorous plants are

short on mercy, some fortunate creatures do
live to fight another day.

title: Flesh Eaters: Carnivorous Plants Lure Insects Into Their Deadly Clutches

comments.author: MR life Guy

comments.text:
+Daniel Carelli What about parts of the world where people don't have 
access to fancy milk, artificial meat, and all that other 
vegan-PETA-approved stuff? For example, vegan-friendly maxipads, medicine, 
dildos, or whatever. In some parts of the world people can't afford this 
stuff, so they either hunt or grow their food. Of course, growing certain 
foods can be quite difficult in some places so it limits their options 
quite significantly. I love almond milk; I think it tastes better and 
settles with my stomach better than regular milk, but it's too expensive to 
purchase regularly. Regular milk, while I can't stand to drink it on its 
own, is just a more convenient purchase. Almond milk is just something that 
I treat myself to on occasion.


Maybe they need to stop making healthy foods and alternatives so expensive 
compared to what people generally buy. Also, don't we eat a lot of the 
foods we eat BECAUSE we want to? People can survive on raw vegetables 
alone, sure, but you and I both know you're going to have a desire to 
enhance it so that it makes it more appealing.
comments.author: CommissarKozlov

comments.text: +UnMeilleurMonde why shouldnt i compare predaters to predators?
comments.author: MR life Guy

comments.text:
+Edulf Lockwood​​ that's simply not accurate. We have vitamins and 
supplements for that, there is no genuine excuse to need to eat meat. We 
don't require it to survive, or even be healthy. Any justifications or 
explanations people make exist solely to cover the fact that they eat meat 
because they want to eat meat.﻿ beyond that, they're just making excuses 
for their behavior.
comments.author: Daniel Carelli (Panentheosis)

comments.text:

http://img2.wikia.nocookie.net/__cb20100505145750/desencyclopedie/images/4/4f/Image_courgette.gif
comments.author: UnMeilleurMonde

comments.text:
+Daniel Carelli I agree human have a choice to eat what they want, but not 
without consequences. Pure vegetarian will never get the nutrients found

comments.author: Edulf Lockwood

comments.text:
+Edulf Lockwood Clearly you didn't understand my point.

Human beings have the ability to not eat meat and remain perfectly healthy. 
Most meat-eating animals do not. There is no biological emperitive for us 
to eat meat, so one should not be used as an excuse to do so.

People who eat meat do so because it is enjoyable and pleasurable to them, 
and they put that pleasure above the right of those animals to live out 
their lives without being food.

That is a personal choice, and people should own the responsibility for it, 
not try and shove it off onto biology. It's a false justification.

This isn't an attack or moral judgement, I eat meat myself; it's just a 
statement of logic and fact. I can admit I eat meat because It's 
pleasurable to. It is a choice, not a need. IMHO, it's disrespectful to the 
animals we eat to pretend otherwise.
comments.author: Daniel Carelli (Panentheosis)

comments.text:
Why are you then advocating human( so much for higher thoughts)  should not 
behave like something we can't really speak for.
comments.author: Edulf Lockwood

comments.text:
+Edulf Lockwood You're asking me a question no human could ever be in a 
position to answer. I can neither speak to, nor speak for, all of the 
animals on this planet.
comments.author: Daniel Carelli (Panentheosis)

comments.text:
I am not speaking for them, I am asking you a question, do animals not just 
wolves enjoy their food?
comments.author: Edulf Lockwood

comments.text:
+Edulf Lockwood ......Well, as soon as you have the ability o actually 
speak for wolves, let me know.
comments.author: Daniel Carelli (Panentheosis)

comments.text:
+Daniel Carelli So wolves eat meat but hate the taste and hunting is not an 
activity they enjoy.
comments.author: Edulf Lockwood

comments.text:
+Daniel Carelli yes its is pleasurable but i eat only because i am a poor 
busy guy who cannot survive physically without eating it, and because i 
cant afford to be a vegetarian.

Besides why should plants be eaten, they have consciousness as well.

Having a higher thought doesnt stop you being a predator, just ask the 
dolphins or whales even the capuchins or chimps or babbons, politicans, 
culture, countries.
comments.author: MR life Guy

comments.text:
O-o Appeal to nature? really? We have higher thought. If you want to eat 
meat because it is pleasurable to you, simply make that argument. We're not 
plants, or wolves, we don't *have* to behave like them.

comments.text:
Flesh Eaters: Carnivorous Plants Lure Insects Into Their Deadly Clutches

SUBSCRIBE: http://bit.ly/Oc61Hj

THESE carnivorous plants make light work of any insects that stray into 
their deadly clutches. This set showcases an array of bug-eating plants, 
from the Venus flytrap - beloved of children the world over - to the Cape 
sundew, which lures insect life in with drops of sweet-smelling fluid on 
the highly-adhesive tentacles that line its leaves. Surrounding tentacles 
then move to further ensnare the insect, before glands on the leaf start to 
release digestive enzymes - liquefying the insect's internal organs and 
allowing them to be digested by the plant. 

Videographer / Director: Francis Chee / Sinclair Stammers / SPL
Producer: Thomas Midlane
Editor: Ian Phillips

For more amazing footage of the amazing side of life, visit the 
Like Barcroft TV on Facebook: http://goo.gl/7ayYgY
Follow Barcroft TV on Twitter: http://bit.ly/10vFLY9
Barcroft Media website: http://bit.ly/19OYwp﻿

comments.text:
+VixXstazosJOB I suppose you're right. I stand by my original point 
however, I'll just test the waters first. Part of my anger is probably for 
the public school system, parents, and this generation of kids, and i'm 
only 25.
comments.author: JCB

comments.text:
+JCB still, *legit* question is *legit* even for someone who is looking for 
some little brief knowledge or explanation that wouldn't hurt anyone though
comments.author: VixXstazosJOB

comments.text:
+Philandros I believe public chastization is an artform and one that can, 
at times be a real eye opener for over-flouridated American public school 
dummies. (I'm from W.V, U.S)

You're right, however... but their username is Lashanti Jones. I'm left to 
assume it's little black girl from some dirty inner-city, that isn't 
expecting the natural selection course on
 qualifiers, variables, and causes.

What do you think?

You seem quite noble!  Perhaps you could take the time to explain such an 
inane question to this person. Who will undoubtedly
forget about this topic, video and subject. 

This person was watching this plant catch and trap insects in this video, 
and their only question is: "Why does the venus fly trap close so fast?"

Am I really the problem here?

Now if said little black girl were asking about the plant's physiologic 
reason for such movement, I would not only be surprised; I would be quite 
impressed.

 I've been reading and responding to people online for about 16 years, so 
far. So I doubt that'll ever happen.

I'll leave you with that, white knightinghood
comments.author: JCB

comments.text:
+JCB
Depends on how in-depth an answer he's looking for..
Also, why do you choose to write a demeaning comment, rather than either 
ignoring or actually answering his comment? Seems rather daft..
comments.author: Philandros

comments.text:
It would take literally 5 seconds of critical thinking for even the daftest 
of people to figure that out..
comments.author: JCB
